results.title: The Travelling tune: a musical phantasy in paper
results.brief_description: A round the world journey in which we see American jazz trumpeters, Venetian goldoliers, Mexican cowboys, Amerstdam canal-side houses, New York skyscrpaers and Bavarian beer mugs. All these scenes are created from colorful paper cutouts.

results.title: The Travel game
results.creator_credit: Tony Thompson, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: As the Hook Continental express leaves Liverpool Street Station, a passenger starts to guess where his fellow passengers are going. In his imagination the journey becomes interwoven with scenes of his travelling companions at their supposed destinations: among the windmills, diamonds and cheeses of Holland; at a Rhine wine festival; on Mount Pilatus in Switzerland; in Denmark and Germany.

results.title: The Trap
results.creator_credit: Alfred Socolow, Leo Trachtenberg and Harvest Films
results.brief_description: Interviews conducted with people who have been injured in the work place by ignoring safety procedures. In-depth accounts of the consequences of incidents that have left workers disabled and scarred by these traumatic events. Re-enactments of accidents that have occurred in the work place, reinforcing the practice of safety procedures.

results.title: The Training dividend
results.brief_description: Examines the need for industry and commerce to institute training programs to improve profitability, and discusses the various forms of assistance provided by the National Training Council.

results.title: The Tobacco problem: what do you think?
results.creator_credit: Kent Smith, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Points out the dangers of smoking by presenting interviews and demonstrations by laboratory scientists and doctors. Emphasises the reasons why people smoke, and includes debate by teenagers on the pros and cons of smoking.

results.title: The Titan: story of Michelangelo (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Richard Lyford, Robert Snyder and Pandora Films
results.brief_description: Covers the life and work of Michelangelo, placing his art in its historical context. This tribute creates a memorable impression of the artist’s greatness and the abundant beauty he willed to the world. Adapted in part from Curt Oertel’s ‘Michelangelo: life of a titan’ with a musical score by the noted German conductor Alois Melichar. Described by filmmaker and critic James Agee as “a new and exciting way to see some of the greatest work ever done”, the film was awarded an Oscar in 1951 for the Best Feature Documentary. Narrated by Fredric March. Presented by Robert Flaherty.

results.title: The Time of your life: the fundamentals of time management
results.brief_description: This film, which is based on Alan Lakein’s book “How to get control of your time and your life”, examines the everyday problems of time management. It looks in particular at the problems of disorganisation, interruptions, paperwork and procrastination, and offers workable solutions to these.

results.title: The Time of your life
results.brief_description: Record numbers of Australians are living longer. The increase in the numbers of elderly people poses problems with the provision of suitable community services including health and accommodation. At the same time society can discriminate against people as they age, depriving them of companionship, dignity and fulfilment. Indeed there is no reason why they should not pass the Century mark, leading full and active lives. Written and narrated by David Goldie.

results.title: The Time of the monster
results.brief_description: An outline of social and political world events in 1933, emphasising the rise to power of Adolf Hitler and his National Socialist Party. Uses newsreel footage from the Associated British Pathe Library.

results.title: The Tim Winton interviews
results.brief_description: Divided into two segments, Tim Winton discusses the work he produces for adult audiences, as typified by his book “Cloudstreet” and the work he produces for a teenage audience as typified by the “Lochie Leonard” books. He discusses his work, his lifestyle, his background and his inspiration.
